tags: Building Uses - office - parking garage; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - postmodern; Materials - glass - granite
column10:
Companies:

• Architect: The Stubbins Associates, Inc. 



• Investors: Equity Office Properties Trust, Lend Lease Real Estate Investments, The Galbreath Company, Jones Lang LaSalle Inc., Yumaque S.A.C., Colliers Turley Martin Tucker, Huber.

• Constructors: Hunt & Nichols Inc. Construction Group, A.J. Armstrong Inc., LeMessurier Consultants, Fink Roberts & Petrie Inc., Omni-Tek Inc., ERMCO, Smith/Roberts & Associates Inc., BMW Constructors Inc., Midland Engineering, Walker Parking Consultants, Service One Inc., Superl Inc., Rowan Williams Davies & Irwin Inc., KONE Inc., Middle Atlantic Products Inc., SMI-Owen Steel Company, Summit Realty Group, Standard Parking.

• Tenants: Ernst & Young, Bank One Corporation, JPMorgan Chase & Co.

____________________________________________________________

Facts & :



• It is the tallest building in Indiana and in the Midwest outside Chicago and Cleveland. 



• Built to be headquarters of American Fletcher National, but merged with Bank One before the completion of construction. Then name was reverted to Chase Tower in late 2005, after Bank One was purchased by JP Morgan Chase & Company.



• Former site of the Hume-Mansur Building, demolished in 1980, and two lowrise buildings, the Board of Trade Building and Bankers Trust Building.



• One spire serves as a communications antenna, while the other is solely decorative.

name: Soldiers & Sailors Monument
tags: Building Uses - monument - museum - observation; Structural Types - tower; Architectural Style - neo-classical; Materials - stone - limestone
column10:
• Architects: Bruno Schmitz, Frederick Baumann.



• Constructors:

American Hydrotech Inc., Enos Hege, Geupel DeMars Inc., Hagerman Construction Corporation, Hale Electric Elevator Company, Indiana Limestone Company, Indiana War Memorial Commission, Jungclaus-Campbell Company Inc., Kite Inc., Pepper Construction Group, Rotz Engineers Inc., Schmidt Associates Inc., Terre Haute Stone Works.

___________________________________________________________



• The 30-foot tall statue at the top is named "Victory."



• The Soldiers and Sailors Monument stands in the very middle of Monument 342-foot diameter Circle, a prominent meeting point in downtown Indianapolis.



• Its estensive renovation by Schmidt Associates and Geupel DeMars was completed in 1989, only recognized in 1990 with the Monumental Award, representing the most significant visual and physical enhancement in Marion County.

 

• There is the Colonel Eli Lilly Civil War Museum located in the monument's lower level.



• Constructed of gray oolitic limestone, the monument commemorates Indiana war dead from 1776-1865.



• The site was once home to the Governor's Mansion, but no Governor ever resided in the house. The empty structure was razed in 1857.



• Its Limestone Sculptures at base are the work of Austrian Sculptor Rudolf Schwarz and the Bronze Astragal, work of Nicolaus Geiger of Berlin.



• The monument was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1973.



• An indoor observation deck at the 244.5-foot level can be reached by a single elevator or stairway.

column10:
• This is the tallest building in Jacksonville since its completion in 1990.



• At night, four of the Bank of America Tower's 8 triangular panels are illuminated, crowning the top of the building and the Jacksonville Skyline.

name: Wells Fargo Center
tags: Building Uses - office - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise - sign; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete
column10:
Architect: KBJ Architects

Developer: Capital Partners

Owner: Wachovia Bank



• The Wells Fargo Center was Jacksonville's tallest building from 1974 to 1990, surpassed by the Bank of America Tower, it was also the tallest building in the state of Florida from 1974 to 1981, surpassed by the Tampa City Center. 



• The building is known for being one of Jacksonville's most prominent skyscrapers, with its oversized signage, glass facade, and slanted base.



• Until the 1990's the building was called Independent Life Building and subsequently renamed Modis Building. Today the tower is known as Wells Fargo Center.

name: AT&T Tower
tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete
column10:
Architect: KBJ Architects



• Originally constructed as the BellSouth Tower, the name was changed in the late 2000's.



• Currently the AT&T Tower is Jacksonville's 3rd tallest building, when it was constructed in 1983 it held the title of 2nd tallest building in Jacksonville.



• The building is known for its visually appealing setbacks, each floor has 16 corners.

name: Riverplace Tower
tags: Building Uses - office - restaurant - fitness center; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete
column10:
Design Architects: Welton Becket and Associates, KBJ Architects 

Contractor: The Auchter Company



• Jacksonville's 5th tallest building as of 2008. When it was completed in 1967 the Riverplace Tower was the tallest building in the state of Florida, it would stay so until the completion of the One Biscayne Tower in Miami in 1972. As for the tallest in Jacksonville, it would stay so until 1974 when surpassed by the Modis Tower. 



• When it was completed in 1967, the Riverplace Tower world's tallest pre-cast, post-tension concrete structure. Most of the building's structural support is on the exterior, leaving more space for the interior.



• The building is home to the University Club, one of Florida's premier private clubs. The University Club is located on the 27th floor.



• The Riverplace Tower's sinage atop the building originally read Gulf Life from 1967 to 1991, when it was changed to SouthTrust. When SouthTrust merged with Wachovia the sign was changed to Wachovia in 2005.

tags: Building Uses - office - communication - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern - postmodern; Materials - glass - steel - marble - granite - concrete
column10:
Architect: BNIM Architects, formally PBNI Architects. (KONE lists it as PBNA)



Structural Engineer: Seiden & Page/Page McNaghten Associates



Elevator Supplier: KONE Inc.



Owner: Executive Hills Management Inc.



General Contractor: Tom Martin Construction



Construction financing: Wells Fargo Realty Advisors Funding



Financing: Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America 



- The inside has black marble, and rose wood with chrome and rose marble accents.



- Has clear glass atriums at corner setbacks with pewter colored glass and black granite cladding of the concrete structure.



- There are 1,200 parking spaces below the skyscraper



- The skyscraper was topped out in 1987



-Total cost was $140,000,000



- 40 floors are office, and 2 are retail



-The lobby is 2 levels due to the height difference in the east and west sides.



-Entrance on Main St. is 879ft above sea level



-Entrance on Baltimore Ave. is 902ft above sea level



http://www.virtualkc.com/ipixmenu.htm (360 Degree View of W. Side)

name: Town Pavilion
tags: Building Uses - office - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - postmodern; Materials - glass - granite
column10:
Architect: Howard, Tammen and Bergendoff  (HNTB)

Property Management: Copaken White Blitt 

Construction Company: J. E. Dunn Construction 



-When viewed from the sky, the building appears to have the same design as a Cathedral with a Latin Cross design and a baptism building near it.

-The Harzfeld Store Building occupied this space before this skyscraper was built.

-The first 3 stories from Main to Walnut and 11th to 12th is retail/mall space.

-A class "A" office building

-There are 2,200 parking spaces in the Town Pavilion facility (surrounding garages) SE of the skyscraper

-Home to more than 36 shops and restaurants 

-The Kansas City Museum's sattelite facility is also located here

-Main entrance is 885ft above sea level

-Eastern side is 886ft above sea level

-Southern/Northern sides are 241' wide

-Eastern/Western sides are 374' wide



Tenants:

-Offices

-Food Court

Great Steak & Fry

Bar Roma

Flamers Charburgers

Joe Joe’s Italian Eatery

Mrs. Field’s Cookies

Papa John’s Pizza

Wrap It Up

Pretzel Time

Panda Express



Links:

http://www.gwhm.com/project_att.shtml http://www.m-e-eker.com/Architecture/

column10:

-Height confirmed as 414ft 5in

-Heights may actually vary as there are different elevations

-Flagpole (spire) height confirmed as 81ft 6in

name: Sheraton Kansas City Hotel at Crown Center
tags: Building Uses - hotel - observation - restaurant - retail - theatre; Structural Types - highrise - revolving floor; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel
column10:
Companies:

• Architect: PBNDML Architects.

• Contractor: Eldridge & Sons Construction.

• Steel/Fabricator: Havens Steel.

• Management: Concordia Project Management Ltd.

• Constructors: Jack D. Gillum & Associates Ltd., Gillum-Colaco International Inc., Daniel Urban Kiley, Edward Larrabee Barnes Associates.

• Incorporations: Greater Kansas City Convention & Visitors Association, Midwest Mechanical Contractors Inc.

• Owner: Global Hyatt Corporation. 

___________________________________________________________



• On July 17th 1981, two 180' skybridges collapsed killing 111 individuals, and injuring 188. Marked as one of the most devastating hotel disasters in the history of the United States.



• Originally set at 42 floors, Hyatt Regency decided to "plop" a revolving restaurant on top making it the tallest in Missouri at the time.

___________________________________________________________



• Link:

http://wireless2.fcc.gov/UlsApp/AsrSearch/asrRegistration.jsp?regKey=117262

name: Kansas City Power & Light Building
tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - art deco - neo-gothic; Materials - limestone
column10:
*landmark*



- Includes a 97' high "pillar" which changes 4 colors, red, white, amber, and green



- Was Missouri's tallest building when completed



- Observation balconies are found at the 32nd floor



- The west wall has no windows, this is because a twin was proposed, but fell through with the hit of the Great Depression



- Kansas City Power and Light no longer occupies the building, having moved in 1992 to the 1201 Walnut Highrise



- Tallest Building in Missouri for 45+ years



- Main entrance is 865ft above sea level



- Eastern side is 862ft above sea level



- Northern side is 872ft above sea level



- Western side is 866ft above sea level



- Eastern side is 130.5' wide



- Southern side is 100' wide



- Architect: Hoit, Price & Barnes



Links:

http://www.kclibrary.org/sc/architecture/profiles/kcpower&light.htm

name: 909 Walnut Tower
tags: Building Uses - residential - office - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - art deco; Materials - brick
column10:
- This building is being converted to apartments, to become Missouri's tallest residential building.



- The two twin towers atop the skyscraper will be converted to three more stories of apartments, raising the floors from 32 to 35 stories.



- This structure has been vacant since 1995.



- Architect: Hoit, Price & Barnes

name: Oak Tower
tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - neo-gothic; Materials - limestone
column10:
- Originally built as a 14 story building rising to a height of 185', the building was expanded in 1929 to twice its original height.



- The building is setback at the 22nd and 25th floors.



- Originally completed in 1919, the building was expanded in 1929.



- Architect: Hoit Price and Barne



- The main entrance on 11th Street lies 6' lower than entrance on the east side along Oak Street

name: AT&T Longlines Building

column10: In Jan. 2005, the antenna, which rose up to 138m from the roof's 95m was removed. It was very very rusty and the local Long Lines people didn't want to spend more money to the FCC to keep an unused tower up so they just took it down.

name: Commerce Tower
tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - international; Materials - glass - stone

management: Grubb&Ellis/The Winbury Group



• City Center Square is Kansas City’s premier high-rise office building located at 'Main and Main' at the center of downtown Kansas City's business district. The 650,000 square foot building provides a vast array of luxury services and amenities including a full-service fitness center, valet parking, new parking garage, conference facilities, on-site ATM and downtown’s most popular food court, making the office building an urban sanctuary for businesses.

name: Charles Evans Whittaker Federal Courthouse
tags: Building Uses - courthouse; Structural Types - highrise; Materials - glass - steel - granite - concrete
column10:
-Has almost 500 employees

-Offices are on the north side, courtrooms are in the center, and public lobbies are to the south of the building

-The stone granite came from Stone Mountain, GA

-12 columns begin in the rotunda and culminate in a circular collonnade outside and above the roof

-The cornerstone of the old YMCA Building that occupied this space many many years ago is placed between the two benches out front, the building was dedicated by former President Grover Cleveland on October 13, 1887

-The dark colored stone is placed at the exact height of the cornice line of the historic KC Library

-The whole project was designed and built on metric measurements, they used meters instead of feet

-The average courtrooms have 19ft ceilings but the 4 courtrooms on the 8th floor have 42ft high ceilings

-Charles E. Whittaker was the only federal judge from Missouri to become a Supreme Court Justice

-The lobby's rotunda is three floors high

-There is a secure restricted space for 100 vehicles inside the structure

-There are 16 courtrooms total

-The lobby rotunda also has five 25ft sculptures

-No two views of the building are symmetric



Architects: Ellerbe Becket & ASAI Architecture

Construction Company: JE Dunn Construction



http://www.jedunn.com/kc/projectexp.asp?projectid=24&category=13v



http://www.hydra.gsa.gov/pbs/pc/nw_files/00/honor_awards/contruction1.htm

name: Liberty Memorial Complex
tags: Building Uses - monument - museum - observation; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - art deco - streamline moderne; Materials - limestone
column10:
**Landmark**



-Liberty Memorial includes a 217' "Memorial Tower"

-The diameter of the tower at the base is 36 feet

-It is the only World War I memorial in America, and is the largest in the world.

-Dedicated by President Calvin Coolidge on Armistice Day, 1926.

-The museum is being expanded and will feature a few more levels of dioramas, scenes, artifacts etc...

-Two Sphinxes guard the south side, Truth, and Memory

-An inscription sits at the base of the tower it says "In honor of all those who served in the world war in defense of liberty and our country"

-The total length of the memorial is 600ft

-The length of the court between memorial buildings is 274ft

-Demensions of memorial buildings: L-93ft W-46ft

-The memorial court stands 143ft above Union Station Plaza (a total height of 360ft above Union Station)

-Diameter of tower at memorial court: 36ft

-Diameter of tower at top: 28ft

-Height of "Guardian Spirits" statues at top: 40ft

-Length of the "Sphinxes": 32ft

-The Great Freize is 148ft long and 18ft high

-Width of memorial court: 154ft



Architect: Harold Van Buren Magonigle

Construction Company: Westlake Construction Company

tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - aluminium
column10:
Floor layout:

- Ground Floor: lobby

- Floors 1-24: office floors

- Floors 25-26: mechanical floors



Front entrance is 4 meters higher than back entrance.



Knoxville's tallest skyscraper.



The 27th floor features a private dining club with spectacular views of the mountains and the Tennessee River.



Built by Jacob "Jake" Butcher for United American Bank. The building was built above a 393 space parking deck.



United American Bank collapsed in 1983 after federal bank regulators uncovered illegal loans, forged documents and other frauds. It was the fourth-largest bank failure in US history.



The building was renovated in 1995.

tags: Building Uses - office - government - parking garage - retail; Structural Types - highrise - clock; Architectural Style - art deco - streamline moderne; Materials - limestone - brick
column10:
- Architect: Hopkins & Dentz



- Owner/Manager: Boji Group



- This has been the tallest building in Lansing since its completion in 1931.



- A 10-story addition was added to the east side of this tower in 1967.  Careful work was done to make it blend in seamlessly with the tower.



- The tower portion of this building was constructed of 3.5 million pounds of structural steel, 654,000 bricks, and in 17 different colors.



- The "Michigan National" neon singage was removed in 2001 after the bank was bought out Standard Federal Bank.  The lettering was 4.5' tall, and each letter weighed 200 to 300 pounds.



- The tower underwent a major renovation in 2004, which included the replacement of all of the windows, among other work completed.

- The 8-story skybridge contains a public restaurant.



- This building incorporates the former Board of Water and Light Building, and a newly constructed 12-story building on the other side of the street, which replaced the demolished 10-story Davenport Building.



- This building houses the offices of the State of Michigan Legislature.

- This is the tallest building of the Sparrow Hospital complex, and one of the tallest buildings outside of downtown in Metropolitan Lansing.



- This building is being completed in three phases, one lasting from 2004 to 2005, one lasting from 2005 until 2006, and one lasting from 2005 to 2008.



- The building will include a helipad on its roof that will service the hospital.

name: Accident Fund Company National Headquarters
tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - art deco - streamline moderne; Materials - limestone - granite - brick - concrete
column10:
- Architect: Bowd-Munson Company



- Owner: Lansing Board of Water and Light



- This Art Deco structure is composed of brick with a granite base, with the brick changing from yellow near the top to purple near the bottom.



- The building was decommissioned by the Lansing Board of Water and Light in 1992, but partially recommissioned in 2001 for the construction of chiller and steam units to serve the downtown area.



- The Accident Fund Insurance Company announced in October of 2007 their plans to renovate the station as their national headquarters.  The renovation, completed by the Christman Company, included adding floors in the existing building, a 4-story, 101,000-square-foot addition directly to the north, and a 1,000-space parking structure.



- The developer removed the station's chimney in December of 2007.  Including the chimney, the station once stood 95.4 meters (313 feet) in height.

name: Stratosphere Tower
tags: Building Uses - observation - communication - religious - restaurant - retail - ride; Structural Types - tower - highrise - roller coaster - vertical ride; Architectural Style - futurism; Materials - glass - steel - concrete, reinforced - concrete
column10:
• Architect: Paul Steelman Design Group.

• Developer: Bob Stupak.

____________________________________________________________



• The Stratosphere Tower has the three highest thrill rides in the world:



1. The Big Shot thrill ride catapults riders from the 921-foot high platform up the Tower's mast to a height of 1,081 feet at 45 miles per hour.



2. At 866 feet, X Scream, Shaped like a giant teeter-totter, X Scream is an open vehicle that propels riders head-first, dangles them weightlessly above the Strip before pulling it's riders back and over again for more.



3. Stratosphere's newest ride, At 906 feet above the ground, Insanity the Ride includes an arm that extends out 64 feet away from the tower that spins passengers, up to three G's , the faster it goes, the higher the ride goes up to 70 degrees.



• The High Roller Coaster was the world's highest roller coaster. The ride is 909 feet above the ground and travels approximately 32 miles per hour. The ride was removed in late 2005 for a more exciting ride.



• The elevators whisk people 109 stories high at 1,800 feet per minute or 3 floors a second.



• The top levels of the tower include a wedding chapel, lounges, a restaurant, observation levels, and thrill rides.



• The mast atop the building is 228' in height, and includes a thrill ride known as the Big Shot.



• During construction, the tower was hit by lightning and caught fire atop the observation pod.



• Considered as a hazard to aviation by the FAA.

name: Palazzo Las Vegas
tags: Building Uses - hotel - casino - parking garage - restaurant - retail - fitness center; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - postmodern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete
column10:
Companies:

• Architect: TSA of Nevada, LLC, HKS, Inc. 

• Owner: Las Vegas Sands, Inc.

___________________________________________________________

Facts & :



• Tallest building in Las Vegas 2007 to present. Expected to be surpassed by the Fontainebleau Resort & Casino in 2009.



• Overall the 3,068 room, 53 story Palazzo Las Vegas cost 1.6 Billion.



• The Palazzo Las Vegas is actually a third expansion to the The Venetian Hotel & Casino. This is the third phase of the resort, phase one included the main 40 story, 3,036 hotel was completed in 1999, the Venezia Tower, a 12 story, 1,013 room hotel tower added over the original 10 story parking garage was added in 2003.

name: Encore at Wynn Las Vegas
tags: Building Uses - hotel - casino - parking garage - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass
column10:
Architect - The Jerde Partnership

Architect - Butler/Ashworth Architects 

Steel supplier - Century Steel, Inc.



Cost - $900 million



Construction started 4/28/06 which is the 1 year anniversary of the resort's opening, and also is Steve Wynn's wife's birthday.



On the site of the recently remodeled and demolished Desert Inn Hotel and Casino.



This is Phase Two of the Wynn Las Vegas Project, and also the Tallest Tower in the Project.



Wynn Las Vegas has the first full-service Ferrari and Maserati dealership on the Strip. Which opened in 2005 along with phase one of Wynn Las Vegas.



It has the only 18-hole golf course on the Las Vegas Strip. The golf course is really the Desert Inn golf course. Many new trees, waterfalls and rivers where added to the golf course when Wynn Las Vegas was under construction.

name: Trump International Hotel Las Vegas
tags: Building Uses - residential - parking garage - residential - restaurant - fitness center; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - gold
column10:
Companies:

- Architect: Bergman, Walls & Associates

- Contractor: Perini Building Company Inc.

- Interior Designer: Design 360 Unlimited

- Property Owner: Hyde Park LLC

___________________________________________________________

Facts& 



- Plans for a Trump Tower in Las Vegas, when the project was announced in 2002, called for a $350 million, 60-story condominium.  Phillip Ruffin in August dropped the expected price to $272 million and said the tower would be 43 stories.



- Then in mid-2004 the project was announced as a $300 million, 64 storey luxury residential hotel condominium tower.



- The Trump Tower Las Vegas will be built in the north section of the Las Vegas Strip, in back of the old New Fronier Hotel & Casino. To the south of the project is the Fashion Show Mall, To the East is Las Vegas Blvd, followed by Wynn Las Vegas.



- On January 4th, 2005 Trump International Hotel & Tower - Tower Two was announced. Tower Two will be an identical second tower that would be added to the Trump International Hotel & Tower Las Vegas.



- In four and a half days all 1,282 units were sold out. On July 15, 2005 the day tower one started construction Trump said "I don't think in the history of Las Vegas that ever happened"



- The tower has 57 floors, although it is marketed as 64 floors. The first level of Condominums above the podium would be floor 16, when in reality its the 9th floor.

name: Wynn Las Vegas
tags: Building Uses - hotel - casino - restaurant - retail - theatre; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern
column10:
Companies:

• Architect: The Jerde Partnership, Butler/Ashworth Architects 

• Steel supplier: Century Steel, Inc.

___________________________________________________________

Facts & :



• Tallest Building in Las Vegas from 2005 - 2007, suprassed by the 53 story Palazzo Las Vegas located right next door.



• On the site of the recently remodeled and demolished Desert Inn Hotel and Casino, it was demolised in 2001.



• Cost: $2.7 billion



• Phase One of the Wynn Las Vegas Project, Phase Two, The Encore at Wynn Las Vegas is expected to open in 2008.



• Wynn Las Vegas opened on April 28, 2005, Ground was broken October 2002. In fall 2001, the Desert in was imploded.



• The Wynn Tower is one of the many hotels in Las Vegas that uses the "window eye trick" . For Example the Tower is 50 stories high but is disguised as a 25 story building. Other Hotels uses this trick to like Caesars Palace, Treasure Island, and the Bellagio.



• Wynn Las Vegas has the first full-service Ferrari and Maserati dealership on the Strip. 



• Wynn Las Vegas has the only 18-hole golf course on the Las Vegas Strip. The golf course is really the Desert Inn golf course. Many new trees, waterfalls and rivers where added to the golf course when Wynn Las Vegas was under construction.

• Both towers were approved November 3rd, 2004 and a groundbreaking for the Casino Spa Tower was held October 25th, 2005.



• The Cosmopolitan Project will have two 51 and 53 story condo-hotel towers the hotel units will be operated by Grand Hyatt. The whole project will have 2,700 units.



• The Cosmopolitan's total cost is $1.8 billion



• Studios units cost around $650,000, 1-bedroom units cost around $1,200,000.

name: Aria Resort & Casino
tags: Building Uses - hotel - casino - conference - office - parking garage - theatre; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - stone - concrete
column10:
Companies:

- Architect: Cesar Pelli & Associates

- Contractor: Perini Building Company

- Owner: MGM Mirage

___________________________________________________________

Project CityCenter Facts & 



- Construction Start: Summer 2006 (Phase One)

- Expected Completion: 2010

- Total Project Cost: $7 Billion, The most expensive privately funded construction project in U.S. History.



- Project CityCenter will include Six Towers, from 37 to 64 stories high, completed between 2009 and 2010.



ARIA RESORT & CASINO

- The centerpiece of Project CityCenter will include two simular towers, the tallest at 62 floors. The 4,100 room, resort & casino was designed by world-reowned architect Cesar Pelli. Also included will be a convention center, offices and parking space. Constuction started 2006, opening expected 2009.



VDARA CONDO HOTEL 

- Vdara will be a strikingly sleek and modern condo-hotel skyscraper. Rising 64 stories high, will be one of the tallest buildings in Las Vegas. Project designed by Rafael Viñoly. Originally designed as a swisting spiral tower, construction started 2006, opening expected 2009.



MANDARIN ORIENTAL LAS VEGAS

- Designed by KPF Architects, the building will feature approximately 400 condominiums and hotel rooms. More than 90% of the project's condominium units where sold after only 14 days. Construction started 2006 on the 56 story building, opening expected 2009.



VEER TOWERS

- The impressive twin towerd Veer Towers will include two "leaning" 37 story condominium buildings. The two ultra-modern skyscrapers will rise over the main Crystals Mall designed by Daniel Libeskind. The Veer Towers where designed by Murphy/Jahn Architects. Consruction started 2007 opening expected 2010.



THE HARMON 

- Designed by world-reowned architects Foster and Partners, The Harmon Hotel, Spa & Casino will rise 40 floors above the Las Vegas Strip. Originally called the Lifestyle Hotel, The Harmon will have an elliptical layout with a highly reflective exterior. Consruction started 2007 opening expected 2010.

• This will be part if the Aladdin Hotel and Casino soon to be Planet Hollywood. But the tower will have different colors than the Aladdin and also a different design.



• The proposed tower will include a 56 story, 600 foot tall tower, 13,495 square feet of restaurants, 947,474 square feet of public areas, and 2,802 resort condominiums with a total floor area of 2,365,061 square feet.



• Planet Hollywood Towers broke ground January 2006.

name: Eiffel Tower at Paris Las Vegas
tags: Building Uses - observation - monument; Structural Types - tower - truss; Materials - steel
column10:
-The Las Vegas Eiffel Tower is only half the size of the original Eiffel Tower in Paris, France.



-Up to 80 people are allowed at the observation deck at the same time.



-The observation deck is half the height of the Stratosphere Tower.



-The Tower is a 5,000 welded-steel structure makeing it stronger than the original tower.



Architect - Leidenfrost/Horowitz & Assocsiates

Owner - Park Place Entertainment

Developer - Hilton Hotels

name: New York New York Hotel & Casino
tags: Building Uses - hotel - casino - restaurant - retail - fitness center; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - art deco - modern - postmodern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete
column10:
Companies:

- Architect: Gaskin, Neal, Marnell Corrao Associates

- Contractor: Marnell Corrao Associates

- Owner: MGM Mirage

___________________________________________________________

Facts & 



- Is a New York Themed Resort and is also the first of the City Themed Resorts.



- The Empire State Building and Chrysler Building Sections are actually have to be called the Empire Tower and Chrysler Tower due to copyright issues.



- The Four Tallest Buildings of the Complex are - The Empire State Building 529 Feet, Chrysler Building - 500 Feet, Century Building – 416ft, and the New Yorker Hotel 370ft.



- The New York Landmarks in this project include - Empure State Building, Chrysler Building, AT&T Building, Mincipal Building, Century Condos, Statue of Liberty, U.S Customs House, Ellis Island, Grand Central Station, and Brooklyn Bridge.



- The New York New York Resort and casino cost $485 million  to build.



- Las Vegas tallest building for 8 years, surpassed by Wynn Las Vegas in spring 2005.



- New York New York has a 83,000-sq.-ft. gaming facility, 6 restaurants, 2,034 guest rooms, a 1.4 million-sq.-ft. hotel tower, 570,000-sq.-ft. of low-rise area, 250,000-sq.-ft. of casino, Multiple food outlets in a New York village streetscape, an Entertainment lounge, a Showroom, Retail Outlets, 180,000-sq.-ft. of back of house support and preparation facilities, a pool area, a roller coaster, and a 1.4 million-sq.-ft. parking garage for 3,850 cars.

- Construction on the Palms Place started in 2005, the official groundbreaking took place May 5th, 2005. It opened on February 29th, 2008.

name: Bellagio Las Vegas
tags: Building Uses - hotel - casino - conference - parking garage - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - postmodern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete

- Associate Architect: WorthGroup

- Owner: MGM Mirage

- Developer: Mirage Resorts Incorporated

___________________________________________________________

Facts & 



- The Bellagio was built upon the site of the Dunes Hotel & Casino which was demolished in 1992.



- The Hotel Tower, and lowrise buildings have a total of 4.8 Million square feet (445,920 m²)



- The Bellagio Resort & Casino costs $1.6 billion makeing it the worlds most expensive building upon completion and the moset expensive Hotel ever built in the world.



- The Bellagio Hotel and Spa Towers is one of the many hotels in Las Vegas that uses the "window eye trick". For Example the Hotel Tower is 37 stories high but is disguised as a 16 story building. 



- Bellagio Las Vegas (Not including the new Spa Tower) has 3,015 hotel rooms, 122,000-sq.-ft. of casino, 150,000-sq.-ft. of convention space, 15 restaurants, 15 retail outlets, an 8-acre man-made lake, 14,000-sq.-ft. conservatory, 8,500-sq.-ft. of gallery space, a 1,800-seat state-of-the-art showroom, a 6-story parking structure, 5,000 stalls of surface parking, 15,000-sq.-ft. of executive offices and 500,000-sq.-ft. of employee and support offices.

name: Sky Las Vegas
tags: Building Uses - residential - conference - garden - parking garage - fitness center; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete

Owner/Developer: Nevada Development Partners

Structural Engineer: Lochsa Engineering

Civil Engineer: The Keith Companies



- The Project Broke Ground in 2005. The project opened late March 2007.



- Sky Las Vegas units cost from $656,000 to $3,699,000. There are four types of Units. One Bedroom, Two Bedroom, Three Bedroom, and suites.



- The five story base will have a parking garage, a private screening room, private meeting room, spa with a fitness center, business center, bar with a billiard room and a social room overlooking the strip. On the Roof of the Base, there will be a recreational area with a dog run, fire pit, barbeque area, putting green, a pool, and gardens.

• Opened on December 17, 2003.



• Restaurant and Lounge ontop in 42nd and 43rd-storeys respectively, these floors are reffered to as the 62nd and 63rd floors. The top "64th" floor, is home to an 18+ nightclub for guests.

• In 1996 Circus Circus Entertainment announced a 400 room hotel and casino called "Project Paradise". Its estimated cost was $700 million at that time. In 1998 "Project Paradise" was renamed Mandalay Bay.



• Resort contains Shark Reef attraction, covering over 90,000 square feet and holding over 1.5 million gallons of water and 100 species of animals.

column10:
- The Signature at MGM Grand will include five 40-45 story condominium towers to be built on the resort property of MGM Grand.



- Studio units cost around $500,000 to $700,000, One-Bedroom units cost around $750,000 to $1,000,000, Two-Bedroom units cost around $1,300,0000 to $2,000,0000.

- Completed late-2006.

name: The Venetian Resort Hotel & Casino
tags: Building Uses - hotel - casino - restaurant - retail - fitness center; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - postmodern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete

General Contractor - Dick Corparation

Facade designer - Enclos Corp.

___________________________________________________________

Facts & :



- Construction Started on the Venetian on April 14, 1997.

The 475 foot tower topped off August 18, 1998. The 1.5 billion resort opened May 3, 1999.



- Original Plans for the Venetian included two towers 3,000 units each, making the Venetian the largest hotel in the world with 6,000 rooms. 



- On the site of the Former 16 Story, Sands Hotel & Casino, which was imploded on November 26, 1996.

tags: Building Uses - residential - fitness center; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - postmodern; Materials - glass - steel
column10:

Companies:

• Architect: Wimberlly Allison Tong & Goo, Bergman, Walls & Associates, Ltd

• Owner: Caesars Entertainment

• Developers: Jay C. Sarno and Marnell Corrao Asssociates.

___________________________________________________________

Caesers Palace Resort & Casino History



1966 - 1970's

• Caesers Palace opened in 1966 with the 16 Story Roman Tower. In 1967 Evel Knievel attempted his famous jump over the Caesers Palace fountains and failed. The 14 Story Centurion Tower was added in 1970, an addition was made to the Roman Tower in 1974. 



1979 - 1980's

• In 1979 the 22 story Fantasy Tower (now Fourm Tower) was constructed. In 1980, at the base of the then Fantasy Tower, the domed Omnimax Theater (later renamed Circus Maximus) was added in 1980. In 1989, Evel Knievel's son, Robbie Knievel attempted and succeeded jumping the Caesars Palace fountains.



1992 - 2000's

• The Caesars Palace Fourm Shops Shopping Mall was completed in 1992, which would expand many times later. In 1997 the 29 Story Palace Tower was completed, along with more shops, convention space, and pools. In 2000, to match the Palace Tower's romanesque design, all three towers where remodeled, along with the demolition of the Omnimax Theatre. 



2001 - Future 

• Circus Maximus was replaced with a new theater, a replica of the Colosseum in 2003. In 2004 the Fourm shops opened its latest and most impressive expansion, bringing the shops to Las Vegas Boulevard. In 2005, the 26 story Augustus Tower was completed, with new shops, wedding chapels and other amenities. In 2009, the 23 story Octavius Tower will be completed, along with more convention space.

name: Veer Towers West
tags: Building Uses - residential - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Materials - glass - steel - concrete
column10:
Companies:

- Architect: Murphy/Jahn Architects

- Contractor: Perini Building Company

- Owner: MGM Mirage



- Part of Block B, Phase One.

___________________________________________________________

Project CityCenter Facts & 



Construction Start: Summer 2006 (Phase One)

Expected Completion: 2009

Total Project Cost: $7 Billion

Number of Towers: Five



- Project CityCenter will include three blocks and two phases, and will be built in two phases:



BLOCK A - Phase One

This is the phase one of Project City Center. Block A will include a Resort/Casino Tower, a Convention Center, A theater, and offices. There will be a large, 62 story high Resort & Casino, which is currently under construction.



BLOCK B - Phase One & Two 

Also part of phase one, that will include two resort condominium towers, a shopping center called the Harmon Place, and a Condo/Hotel Tower. The two resort condominium towers will be 585 feet high and will have a curveing design. The Towers will be called Veer Las Vegas. The Condo/Hotel tower will be 64 stories high and will be called the Vinoly Resort Condominiums.



BLOCK C - Phase Two

This part of the project will be phase two. Block C will include two towers: a Lifestyle Hotel and a Mandarin Oriental Hotel, one on the northeastern corner and one on the southern side. There will also be another shopping mall.

name: Veer Towers East
tags: Building Uses - residential - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete
column10:
Companies:

- Architect: Murphy/Jahn Architects

- Contractor: Perini Building Company

- Owner: MGM Mirage

___________________________________________________________

Project CityCenter Facts & 



- Construction Start: Summer 2006 (Phase One)

- Expected Completion: 2010

- Total Project Cost: $7 Billion, The most expensive privately funded construction project in U.S. History.



- Project City Center will include Six Towers, from 37 to 64 stories high, completed between 2009 and 2010.



PROJECT CITYCENTER RESORT & CASINO

- The centerpiece of Project City Center will include two simular towers, the tallest at 62 floors. The 4,100 room, resort & casino was designed by world-reowned architect Cesar Pelli. Also included will be a convention center, offices and parking space. Construction started 2006, opening expected 2009.



VDARA CONDO HOTEL 

- Vdara will be a strikingly sleek and modern condo-hotel skyscraper. Rising 64 stories high, will be one of the tallest buildings in Las Vegas. Project designed by Rafael Viñoly. Originally designed as a swisting spiral tower, construction started 2006, opening expected 2009.



MANDARIN ORIENTAL LAS VEGAS

- Designed by KPF Architects, the building will feature approximately 400 condominiums and hotel rooms. More than 90% of the project's condominium units where sold after only 14 days. Construction started 2006 on the 56 story building, opening expected 2009.



VEER TOWERS

- The impressive twin towerd Veer Towers will include two "leaning" 37 story condominium buildings. The two ultra-modern skyscrapers will rise over the main Crystals Mall designed by Daniel Libeskind. The Veer Towers where designed by Murphy/Jahn Architects. Construction started 2007 opening expected 2010.



THE HARMON 

- Designed by world-reowned architects Foster and Partners, The Harmon Hotel, Spa & Casino will rise 40 floors above the Las Vegas Strip. Originally called the Lifestyle Hotel, The Harmon will have an elliptical layout with a highly reflective exterior. Construction started 2007 opening expected 2010.

name: Treasure Island Hotel & Casino
tags: Building Uses - hotel - casino - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - postmodern; Materials - masonry
column10:
Companies:

- Architect: Bergman, Walls & Associates, Ltd., The Jerde Partnership 

___________________________________________________________

Facts & :



- As an expansion to the Mirage, another Steve Wynn hotel across the street, it was going to be called "Treasure Island At the Mirage."



- Construction on Treasure Island started March 1992 and opened October 1993.



- Originally a largely family themed resort, Treasure Island abandoned its family theme in 2003 and switched to a more contemporary resort. Gone are the famous skull-and-crossbones sign, video arcade, and free pirate show. The hotel was renamed TI: Treasure Island.



- The hotel is home to "Buccaneer Bay," a mock oceanfront village, including a man-made lake facing the Strip. Originally, a nightly show for visitors and tourists featured "Pirates vs. the English Navy" aimed at a younger audience. When the hotel shifted to a more contemporary style, it was replaced with adult themed "Sirens of TI" and the lake was renamed "Sirens Cove". The show focuses around a group of sensual Sirens seducing a band of renegade pirates.

• Harrah's Las Vegas was originally opened as Holiday Casino in 1973, as a one-tower hotel and casino designed by Homer Rissman. Holiday Casino underwent two major expansions in 1983 (adding Mardi Gras North Tower, designed by Rissman) and 1989 (adding the Carnival Tower, designed by Martin Stern Jr). The complex was renamed Harrah's Las Vegas in 1992.

- This was the second addition to the Sahara Hotel & Casino.



- When the Sahara Alexandria Tower was completed in 1963, it was the tallest hotel building in Ten Western States.



- Tallest building in Las Vegas 1963-1967.



- The Deluxe rooms of the Sahara are located in the Alexandria Tower.  Each room is equipped with an individually controlled heating and cooling system. Some suites are also located in this tower.



- The broundbraking ceremony was held on February 9, 1962. The Alexandria Tower opened on May 24, 1963.



- The world famous rock band: the Beatles played at the Sahara in 1963 and stayed in room 2344 of the Alexandria Tower.



- When the tower opened there where only two towers at the Sahara, the 14 story Tunis Tower and the Alexandria Tower. The Tunis Tower had a time and tempature sign on top of the tower for three years, it was moved to the Alexandria Tower when it opened on May 24, 1963. today the sign no longer exists.

name: Forum Tower
tags: Building Uses - hotel - casino - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - romanesque; Materials - glass - steel - stucco
column10:
Companies:

• Architect: Marnell Corrao Associates 

• Owner: Caesars Entertainment

___________________________________________________________

Caesers Palace Resort & Casino History



1966 - 1970's

• Caesers Palace opened in 1966 with the 16 Story Roman Tower. In 1967 Evel Knievel attempted his famous jump over the Caesers Palace fountains and failed. The 14 Story Centurion Tower was added in 1970, an addition was made to the Roman Tower in 1974. 



1979 - 1980's

• In 1979 the 22 story Fantasy Tower (now Fourm Tower) was constructed. In 1980, at the base of the then Fantasy Tower, the domed Omnimax Theater (later renamed Circus Maximus) was added in 1980. In 1989, Evel Knievel's son, Robbie Knievel attempted and succeeded jumping the Caesars Palace fountains.



1992 - 2000's

• The Caesars Palace Fourm Shops Shopping Mall was completed in 1992, which would expand many times later. In 1997 the 29 Story Palace Tower was completed, along with more shops, convention space, and pools. In 2000, to match the Palace Tower's romanesque design, all three towers where remodeled, along with the demolition of the Omnimax Theatre. 



2001 - Future 

• Circus Maximus was replaced with a new theater, a replica of the Colosseum in 2003. In 2004 the Fourm shops opened its latest and most impressive expansion, bringing the shops to Las Vegas Boulevard. In 2005, the 26 story Augustus Tower was completed, with new shops, wedding chapels and other amenities. In 2009, the 23 story Octavius Tower will be completed, along with more convention space.

column10:
- The former Maxim Hotel was renovated and reopened as the Westin Casuarina on November 6, 2003. The building's exterior was notibly revamped from a glass facade to its current form.



- The Maxim's casino closed in 1999, leasing the hotel to close in 2001 due to disputes between the casino operator and hotel owners. It did not reopen until 2003 as the Westin Casuarina.



- The Maxim was the site of the shooting death of famous rapper Tupac Shakur in 1996.

column10:
Architect: Wou & Partners



The Long Beach World Trade Center was originally conceived as a massive complex of five towers, one reaching 650 feet. Unfortunately, only phase one's 30 storey tower and Hilton hotel were completed. 



The current owners of the WTC property plan to build a second office tower and two 20+ storey residential structures.

name: Villa Riviera Apartments
tags: Building Uses - residential; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - neo-gothic; Materials - steel - concrete
column10:
Located on a beachfront bluff at 800 East Ocean Boulevard in Long Beach, California, groundbreaking for the Villa Riviera building began in December of 1927 with opening day planned for December 1928.  



The project was conceived and developed by Lionel V. Mayell, successful developer of other classic Long Beach high rises such as the Cooper Arms and the Artaban.  Mayell’s concept utilized local architect Richard D. King’s design of a 20 floor Gothic revival high-rise that won 1st place in an international contest.  



At the time of completion, the Villa was only 3 feet shorter than the tallest building in southern California - Los Angeles City Hall at 464 feet.  



As with most of Mayell’s many projects both here and on the east coast, “The Villa” was originally conceived and operated as luxury “stock co-operative” (or “own-your-own”) residential apartments, not as a hotel or rental units as is widely believed. It wasn’t until after the Stock Market crash and infamous Long Beach earthquake that the Mortgage Guarantee Company was forced to foreclose on Mayell’s cooperative in 1933.  



This began a period of hotel operation for the Villa, which went through a succession of owners for the next 22 years.



The building astonishingly survived the devastating 1933 Long Beach Earthquake with mostly superficial cosmetic damage, due in no small part to Richard King’s extensive studies of the effects of earthquakes in Japan just prior to designing the Villa.  



Shortly after foreclosure, Mortgage Guarantee installed a neon Art Deco “Apartment-Hotel” sign over the entrance in 1934 and continued to run the building until 1937, when Joseph M. Schenck of Twentieth Century-Fox bought it for his ex wife/silent film star Norma Talmadge.  



As the “Villa Riviera Company” they had aspirations of huge additions and remodeling, but fortunately they defaulted on their loan and Mortgage Guarantee leased the building to Consolidated Hotels for its operations beginning in 1940.  After that lease expired, the building was auctioned off to the Burger Hotel Company in 1943, and was again sold to hotelier George Allen in 1946.  



During this time, the Villa was commonly referred to as the “Home of Admirals” as many officers in the U.S. Navy occupied it. To this day, a brass US Geological Survey (USGS) plaque is still embedded on the balcony of the Villa's tower demonstrating its historical importance to ocean going-vessels along the coast.  



It was also during this time that many significant “improvements” and modifications were done or attempted by Allen, including the circle driveway, a 2nd neon sign on the tower, nightclub in the garage, fountain on the front lawn, and further lobby remodeling.  In 1954 Allen sold the hotel to the Morris Hotel Chain of Beverly Hills, who also operated other hotels such as the Hotel Clark in Los Angeles and the Hotel San Diego.  



The hotel operation would last only 1 more year and in 1955 the building was again sold-off to what was called the Villa Holding Company.  



This company reverted many of the past hotel modifications so the building could again become residential, and the units were sold off as individual “own-your-own” apartments.  



During the 1970s the building was threatened with condemnation due to strict enforcement of new fire codes, but the struggling association managed to raise enough money to enclose the spectacular open staircases and install fire rated doors and sprinklers throughout.  



In 1979 the Villa was designated a historical landmark by Long Beach Cultural Heritage, but by the late 1980s the Villa was ironically imperiled (along with countless other Long Beach structures) by the demands of new earthquake codes.  



Once again the homeowner’s association met this new challenge by installing the required retrofits.  In 1991 the association was converted to condominium titles, and the Villa finally earned its rightful place on the prestigious National Register of Historic Places in 1996.    



As always, the Villa continues to thrive as downtown’s pre-eminent landmark, and is the subject of many writings, art projects, movie locations, photos, special events, and promotional literature and public murals.



-From "Villa Riviera: A General History"

column10:

• Executive Architect: Ellerbe Becket Associates.

• Structural: CBM Engineers, Inc.



• Los Angeles Business Council: Beautification Award: New Commercial High Rise (1990).

• California Geotechnical Engineers Association Outstanding Project Award (1989).

___________________________________________________________



• Tallest building at West Coast.



• Tallest building in the world to be completed in the 1980's.



• Part of Library Square, a project including two towers next to the newley renovated Los Angeles Central Library including the 73 floor First Interstate World Center and 52 story SoCal Gas Center. Today US Bank Tower and Gas Company Tower.



• It has the world's highest helicopter landing pad, and signage (company logo).  Helicopter landing pads are required on Los Angeles skyscrapers for evacuation purposes, leading to L.A.'s flat-topped skyline.



• Construction Started on the US Bank Tower on June 1987 and opened in late 1989. 



• The tower stands at 1,018 feet, when it was completed in 1989 it was the 7th Tallest Building in the Nation. Due to the destruction of the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center during 9/11, the U.S. Bank Tower (then Library Tower) became the 5th tallest in the country. The U.S. Bank tower is expected to lose this title in 2008, with the completion of the 92 floor Trump International Hotel & Tower in Chicago. The U.S. Bank Tower will then fall into 6th place. 



• This building can withstand a 8.3 richter scale earthquake. The major San Andreas Fault cannot produce a 8.0 or greater earthquake. However, there are many unknown and newly discovered faults in the area, including one that runs right through Downtown.



• The glass crown on top of the tower lights up the LA skyline at Night.



• The Building has 73 floors, 66 of them are offices while the rest are mechanical, restaurants, and lobbies.



• Featured in such movies like Independence Day (1996), The Day After Tomorrow (2004) and Transformers (2007).

name: Aon Center
tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise - landing pad - sign; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete, reinforced
column10:
• Architect: Charles Luckman, Luckman Partnership Inc.



• Owner: Transwestern Investment Company.

• Others: Jones Lang LaSalle Americas, Standard Parking.

___________________________________________________________



• Building Size: 1,028,852 sq².

• Building Class: A.



• This it the tallest skyscraper in California from 1974 to 1990 and tallest building west of the Mississippi River from 1974-1982 surpassed by the JP Morgan Tower in Houston, Texas. Tallest in los angeles until the completion of US Bank Tower in 1989.



• On May 4, 1988 a fire started on the 12th floor, injured 40 and killed one person. The fire destroyed 5 floors.



• 7 out of the top 10 Skyscrapers in Los Angeles have logos on top, The Aon Center has a history of logos today it says "Aon" on top.



• In the past the Aon Center was called the First Interstate Tower, Wells Fargo Tower, United California Plaza, and 707 Wilshire Blvd.



• An extra 579-cars garage, which is located on 637 wilshire boulevard and which is connected through a tunnel to the 243-cars garage under the tower.



• A center elevator core, with 3 stairs' shafts, mechanical floors on floors  4, 5, 22, 42, 61 and 62 and cafeteria on 6th floor and restaurant on 60th one. Each floor has area of 1626 m².

• Each regular floor has a floor area of about 2423 m².

name: Rosslyn Hotel
tags: Building Uses - hotel; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - beaux arts; Materials - masonry - steel
column10:
The Hotel Rosslyn has a history unique in all of the city of Los Angeles.



Once the tallest building in LA, the Rosslyn boasted in it's large rooftop sign as being the "Fireproof Million Dollar Hotel."



It's best years are behind it now, seeing some minor glory in 1987 as the rooftop site of U2's music video for "Where the Streets Have no Name."



Today the Rosslyn is a flop house, with rooms going for $8 a night. The seedy side of downtown Los Angeles lives here now (2003).

Originally built as a 20,142-seat arena located on Memphis' downtown Riverfront



The Pyramid fell into disuse between 2004 and 2015 after losing its professional sports tenants to the opening of the FedEx Forum



It was repurposed in 2015 as a Bass Pro Shops "megastore", featuring shopping, a hotel, restaurants, a bowling alley, an archery range, and an outdoor observation deck at its apex



The facility is owned by the City of Memphis

Design architect: Gary Edward Handel + Associates 

Structural engineer: DeSimone Consulting Engineers, P.L.L.C.



The pinnacle height is 781'3" NGVD, or 776'3" (236.6m) above grade.  The highest roof is at 765'5" NGVD, or 760'5" (231.8m) above grade.  The common height of 788'9" (240m) is incorrect.  We received this information from the Project Manager.

name: Wachovia Financial Center
tags: Building Uses - office - parking garage - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - marble - granite
column10:
- Management/Leasing: Cushman & Wakefield of Florida, Inc. 



- The tower was chosen by the Wall Street Journal as one of the 50 best buildings in the United States.



- This was the tallest Building in Florida from its completion in 1984 to the completion of the Four Season Hotel & Tower in 2003.  The tower simply reverted back to its lesser title of tallest office building in Florida.



- The 55th Floor is home to the Miami City Club.



- The Wachovia Financial Center has a skybridge on the 14th floor, connecting to the 14 story Parking Garage Building, the 14th floor is home to the Downtown Athletic Club.



Awards Won:

- TOBY Building of the Year 1990

- TOBY Building of the Year 1996

- TOBY Building of the Year 1999

- This has been the tallest building in the state of Wisconsin since its completion in 1973.



- The exterior of this building is composed of 66% glass with a total of 5,000 windows.



- The site of this building slopes 15' from Michigan Street up to Wisconsin Avenue.



- The building is constructed in such a way, that a twin tower can be added over the expansive, two-story lobby that extends outward from the building.

- Architect: Edward F. Baker & Associates, Johnson/Burgee

- Developer: Investors Diversified Services

- Owner: Inland Real Estate Group



- The IDS Centre was a landmark building for Minneapolis ushering a new era of development for it's skyline and replaced the Foshay Tower (136m) as the city's tallest.



- The IDS Center incorporates the 57 story IDS Tower, 8 story 770 Marquette, Marquette Hotel, and a bi-level mercantile area surrounding the central courtyard covered by a cascading glass roof.



- Each floor of the IDS Tower includes 32 corner offices due to its numberous setbacks.

name: Capella Tower
tags: Building Uses - office - parking garage; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - postmodern; Materials - glass
column10:
• Architect: Pei Cobb Freed & Partners 

• Associate Architect : HKS, Inc.

• Developer: Joint Venture of IBM Corporation and

The OPUS Corporation

• Structural Engineer: CBM Engineers Inc. 



• Third tallest building in Minneapolis and tallest building in Minneapolis to be completed in the 90's.



• Completed in 1992 as the headquarters for 1st Bank, later US Bancorp, until 2002 when US Bancorp moved its headquarters to the 32 story building at 800 Nicolett Mall.



• The semi-circle located atop the tower is not only for decoration but also serves as a screen for the cooling towers and other mechanical equipment. The feature has given the nickname the "Halo Building" or "Stanley Cup Building".



• The building stands on an "L" shaped footprint.

name: Wells Fargo Center
tags: Building Uses - office - mechanical - museum - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - art deco - postmodern; Materials - glass - steel - stone
column10:
Companies:

- Architect(s): Cesar Pelli & Associates Architects, Kendall/Heaton Associates Inc. 

- Owner/Developer: Hines Interests Limited Partnership

___________________________________________________________

Facts & 



- The Wells Fargo Center is on the site of the old Northwestern National Bank Building, which was destroyed by a fire in 1982.



- The Wells Fargo Center was the tallest building completed in Minneapolis during the 1980s. 



- The upper setbacks are illuminated at night by floodlights. The Wells Fargo Center's Golden Crown and can easily be seen for miles. 



- The Wells Fargo Center's architectural design is a modern/postmodern art-deco style.



Awards

- Urban Land Institute Award for Excellence for Large-Scale Office Development, 1989.

- BOMA Local Building of the Year, 1993. 

- BOMA Regional Office Building of the Year, 1994.

column10:
Architect: Hammel, Green & Abrahamson, Inc. 



- The upper part of the tower became illuminated with a new lighting scheme in June 2006.  



- Floors 5, 6, 34 and 35 are mechanical floors, the 42nd floor is a mechanical penthouse.



- Was the Piper Jaffray Headquarters until 2002 when it was renamed after Piper Jaffray was purchased by US Bank, which moved its headquarters to the new US Bancorp Center located near the Nicollet Mall. 



- Tallest building in Minneapolis designed by a locally-based architectural firm.



- The Campbell Mithun Tower has a restaurant, deli, convenience store, hair salon, coffee shop, dry cleaners, insurance agency, dentist, sushi bar, and a travel agency.

column10:
Architect: Elerbe Becket



Developer: Ryan Companies

___________________________________________________________



- This is the northernmost of 3 contiguous blocks from 1998-2001 including also 900 Nicollet Plaza and Target Plaza.



- The only major office building with its primary axis oriented parallel to Nicollet Mall, occupying the entire west side of the block between 8th and 9th Streets.

  

- The building is connected by skyway to the Macy's Department Store Addition and 900 Nicollet Plaza.

  

- This site was formerly occupied by several low-rise buildings, including 808 Building.



- This was the second tallest office building completed in the United States during 2000, after only the Ameriprise Financial Center, also in Minneapolis.

column10:
Architect: Skidmore, Owings & Merrill LLP 

Developer: Hines Interests Limited Partnership

Tenant: Ernst & Young



• This is New Orlean's tallest and largest building.



• The facade is made of tavertine stone, with bronzed glass windows.



• One Shell Square has a similar design to Houston's One Shell Plaza completed one year earlier, and was also designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill LLP. Houston's One Shell Plaza is just five meters taller.



• Was the tallest building the Southeastern United States from 1972 to 1976 when the Westin Peachtree Plaza in Atlanta surpassed it.



• One Shell Square was the first southern skyscraper to surpass the 200 meter mark.

column10:
Architect: Leonard Spangenberg, Jr. & Associates



• The tower was originally designed primarily as an office tower, but had room for residential areas on the top floor.  The top floors were never used as residential space, though.



• Construction of this tower started in 1964, but was halted in October of 1966, when the property was bought out.  It resumed construction in 1968, and was completed the following year.



• The building was officially shuttered in 2002, as it had been poorly maintained, and was filled with asbestos and toxic mold.



• This building is planned for restoration, complete with a new facade.  It will be converted from office space to luxury condominium units.

name: One World Trade Center
tags: Building Uses - office - communication - mechanical - observation - restaurant - retail - station; Structural Types - highrise - pole; Architectural Style - modern - structural expressionism; Materials - glass - steel - concrete, reinforced
column10:
• Companies:

- Architect(s): David Childs; Skidmore, Owings & Merrill

- Developer: Port Authority of New York & New Jersey

- Owner: Port Authority of New York & New Jersey

- Construction Manager: Tishman Construction Corporation

- Structural Engineer: Cantor Seinuk Group

___________________________________________________________

Facts & :



• Part of the New World Trade Center, which is expected to be completed in 2012 - 2013. Link to Project Diagram:

http://skyscraperpage.com/diagrams/?buildingID=7788,7801,7802,7803,7804,7422&orderby=buildingIDorder



• The building will be the tallest in New York City and the country upon completion, and one of the tallest in world. 



• The building has been renamed by the Port Authority (owner) in spring 2009 from Freedom Tower to One World Trade Center. 



• This is the buildings second official design. The first, designed by David Childs in collaboration with Daniel Libeskind, was disregarded due to concerns raised by the New York Police department that the building would be vulnerable to a car bomb blast. The second design was planed by David Childs of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill (SOM) and was made public in 2006, shortly before construction started.



• The roof height is the same as original One World Trade Center. The building is topped out by a 124-meter (408-foot) spire. So the tower rises 1,776 feet (541-meter) which marks the year of the American declaration of Indepedence. The spire's tip is considered to architectural top of the building (simiular to other new skyscrapers) because it was designed for this highrise as such and not only as an antenna.



• The building now officialy 105 Floors tall, instead of 82. The base will occupy floors 1 - 19, Floors 20 - 63 will be offices, floor 64 will be a skylobby, floors 65 - 88 will also be offices. Floors 89 - 99 will be Mechanical floors, floors 100 - 102 will be used for Observation and other public uses. Floors 103 - 105 will then be more Mechanical Floors. 



• The new design attempts to address the NYPD's concerns with its 186.5-foot-high reinforced concrete blast resistant base, which will contain the Freedom Tower's 80-foot tall lobby and three of its mechanical floors. 



• The base of the tower, which was originally to be clad in polished steel and titanium like 7 WTC, will now be covered in vertical bands of glass prisms. The base will have no windows except for several tall narrow ones which will be placed a minimum of 25 feet above the ground.



• The cornerstone of One WTC was laid in July 2004, before the redesign was deemed necessary. The stone was then removed in mid 2006 as foundation work for the tower began. Foundation work is fully completed in 2009 and the towers steel begun to rise towards the sky. Expected topping out is in 2012 and completion is planned in 2013 with a total cost of more than 3 billion US-$.

 

• After lengthy and combative negotiations that resulted in a reconfigured lease agreement between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey (the owner of the World Trade Center) and Larry Silverstein (the leaseholder of the complex), construction of the Freedom Tower began on April 27, 2006. Not long after the start of construction, a new battle with the insurers of the World Trade Center resulted from the reconfiguration of the lease. The court battle now threatens to delay or end construction.

___________________________________________________________



• More information about One WTC can be found at:



- Port Authority: http://wtcprogress.com/

- Silverstein Properties: http://www.wtc.com

name: Empire State Building
tags: Building Uses - office - communication - observation - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - art deco; Materials - steel - limestone - aluminium - granite - concrete
column10:
• The Empire State Building is one of the most famous skyscrapers in the world, built in just 18 months during the Great Depression, it was the world's tallest building in 1931–1972 (also world's tallest structure till 1954 and free-standing one till 1967).



• It's original cost, including the price of land, was $40,948,000, a very low figure for a building of this size even at that time. The building itself cost only $24,718,000.



• The Empire State Building was built on the former site of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.



• The shape of the Empire State Building was inspired by its developer, John Jakob Raskob, who is said to have pulled a pencil from his drawer, held it up to his architect (William Lamb), and asked "Bill, how tall can you make it so that it won't fall down?" 



• The observation tower at the top of the Empire State Building was originally intended to be a dock for mooring airships. However, after several futile attempts at mooring a zeppelin in the strong winds present at 1250 feet, the idea was scrapped.



• On a Saturday, July 1945, a B-25 bomber crashed into Empire State Building's 79th floor, which housed the Catholic War Relief Services. Only 14 people died and the Empire State Building reopened 2 days later.



• The top of the Empire State Building is lit up at night in different colors to celebrate various holidays. For a long time after Sept. 11, 2001, it was continuously lit red, white, and blue.



• The height of the antenna has been decreased from 448.7 meters (1472 feet) to 443.2 meters (1454 feet).



• After 09.11.2001, it regained its title as the tallest building in NYC, lost from the destruction of WTC twin towers. ESB was surpassed by One World Trade Center in 2013.



• The 86th floor observatory is visited by 3.5 milllion people every year. 



• Member of "World Federation of Great Towers".

name: Bank of America Tower
tags: Building Uses - office - parking garage - retail - theatre; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - structural expressionism; Materials - glass - steel - concrete, reinforced
column10:
Companies:



• Architect: Cook + Fox Architects, LLP, Adamson Associates International. 



• Development: The Durst Organization / Bank of America.

• Constructors: Tishman Construction Corporation, Cornell & Company, Inc., Century-Maxim Construction Corporation, Severud Associates, Link-Belt Construction Equipment Company, Schindler Elevator, ULMA Form Works, Inc., Viracon, altPOWER Inc.

• Engineers: Mueser Rutledge Consulting Engineers, Entek Engineering LLP, Jam Consultants Inc., Solar Design Associates, Inc., Van Deusen & Associates (New York), Steven Winter Associates, Inc, Israel Berger & Associates, Ducibella Venter & Santore, Vollmer Associates LLP.

• Lights: Cline Bettridge Berstein Lighting Design Associates. 

• Tenant: Bank of America. 

____________________________________________________________



• Investment: $1 Billion.



• Ground was broken starting construction on 1 Bryant Park during a morning ceremony on August 2nd 2004. In attendance was Governor Pataki of New York, Mayor of New York Michael R. Bloomberg, and Kenneth D. Lewis, president and CEO of Bank of America. Remington Building was the tallest building demolished to make way for this tower. 



• Bank of America is the anchor tenant of 1 Bryant Park, now the Bank of America Tower.



• It is expected that this building is LEED certified "Platinum" making it the first such skyscraper in the world. To achieve this, the property features "green" technology including a deep double-walled insulated facade, rooftop rain collection, filtered under-floor displacement air ventilation, a wind turbine, a 4.6-megawatt cogeneration plant, and a garden. The building is also be built largely of recycled ; Materials and/or have ; Materials sourced from no further than 500 miles from the site. Standing right next to another "green" skyscraper pioneer, 4 Times Square, the building is to have groundbreaking environmental features such as being able to generate 70% of its energy and gather all of its toilet water. 



• It provides home for Historic-Rebuilt Henry Miller Theater, as well as new Subway entrances and an underground pedestrian walkway, between the 6 th and 7 th avenue subway lines. 



• The building has a spire/antenna that will reach 1200 feet. In reality has two spires, the 365.76 meter (1200 foot) one is architectural and the 292.61 meter (960 foot) one is a wind turbine that would generate electricity for the building. The southern roof would rise to 287.88 meters (944 feet 6 inches) and the northern roof would rise to 258.47 meters (848 feet).  



• During its construction, a container felt of top crane, damaging some windows, to be replaced in facade. No one died but had injuries.

____________________________________________________________



• Info Page: http://www.nyc-architecture.com/MID/MID157.htm

Project Architect: FXFowle Architects.



- The building is anchored by the New York Times newspaper (floors 1 through 28) with other tenants on the remaining floors.  The design life is expected to be 100 years.



- Double layered facade: A system of small ceramic tubes covering transparent glass which permit the tubes to show the color of the sky.  The Times headline above the 8th Ave. entry is printed in 10,166 pt. Fratur font.



- Plantings and gardens are also be placed at the roof top and within an internal open air atrium inside the podium.



- While the building does make use of current energy saving technology, it is not expected to become LEED certified.



- Upper section of spire is designed to sway slightly in the wind.



- Fourth tallest building in New York as of 2010, behind the Empire State Building, Bank of America Tower and Chrysler Building.

name: Chrysler Building
tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise - pole; Architectural Style - art deco; Materials - masonry - steel - stone - marble - concrete
column10:
Companies

___________________________________________________________

Facts & 



• Tallest building in the world from 1930 to 1931.



• Originally, the building had an observation deck, this deck was closed when the Empire State Building opened and has since been converted into office space.  



• Cost: $15 million.



• The Chrysler Corporation moved out and sold the building in the mid-1950s.



• William Van Alen designed a 185ft (56.3m) spire, inspired by a car radiator grill, which was raised to the top in 90 minutes, surpassing 40 Wall Street, and the Eiffel Tower as the tallest structure in the world.



• 391,831 rivets were used to make the Chrysler Building.



• The "Cloud Club" was a private lounge area at the top of the building where people could rest and in the times of prohibition, had a hidden room. On the 2nd floor of the Cloud Club, Chrysler had a private lounge.



• The 71st floor observation deck has triangular windows, with the walls having stars and the lights appeared as saturn. It is now leased to tenants.



• In 1945 the observation deck was closed, the Cloud Club followed in the 1970's.



• When the Chrysler Building was being fixed up, they found that all 3,800 windows were fine. The spire however leaked which was fixed, renovation was finished in 2002.

____________________________________________

Facts & 



- Will be converted to residential use.



- World Headquarters of the American International Group, now usually referred to as AIG.  



- This building was built for the Cities Service Company, a utility business. Cities Service later became CITGO.  It sold the building to American International in 1976 when it moved its headquarters to Tulsa, Oklahoma.



- The building has an small but sumptuous enclosed glass observatory just under its spire on the 66th floor, as well as an open-air viewing platform just below it. However, both the platform and observatory are now closed to the public, and can only be accessed by AIG executives and employees.  



- This building makes an appearance at the end of the movie "Spiderman", though it has been "moved" to Midtown for the scene.



- After the September 11th terrorist attacks, the American International building was once again the tallest building in Lower Manhattan until surpassed by the new World Trade Center towers.

- Previous designs were 868 feet and a twin towered concept of 420 feet.
